title: Facile isolation of high-affinity nanobodies from synthetic libraries using CDR-swapping mutagenesis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Recovering and inducing yeast libraries
Timing: 3 days
Yeast libraries are refreshed in growth media (SDCAA) prior to use in sorting. This growth step can be used to allow the library to recover after previous storage of the frozen library. Transferring the nanobody library to induction media (SDGCAA) then promotes nanobody expression on the surface of yeast cells for sorting.
Thaw a frozen aliquot of the nanobody yeast library on the benchtop at room temperature.
The frozen library aliquot has >10-fold coverage of the diversity with >109 cells.
Add thawed yeast cells to 500 mL of SDCAA media in baffled flask.
Supplement SDCAA media with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Incubate the flask at 30°C at 225 RPM for 18–24 h.
Calculate the cell density by measuring the optical density at 600 nm (OD600). One OD600 unit is equivalent to approximately 3 × 107 cells/mL.
Calculate the volume of cells required to seed 500 mL SDGCAA culture at a final OD600 of 1.
Centrifuge the required number of cells at 2500×g for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells in SDGCAA, and move the cells to a 500 mL SDGCAA culture in shake baffled flask.
Supplement SDGCAA media with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Incubate the flask at 20°C at 225 RPM for 36–48 h.
Note: Yeast induction could be performed at 30°C for 18–22 h or at 20°C for 36–48 h. In certain cases, longer induction times help with higher surface expression.
Magnetic-activated cell sorting, MACS (sort 1)
Timing: 5 h

Initial MACS selections allow for the processing of a large number of cells (108–109) in early rounds of sorting. In order to ensure full processing of the entire library diversity, approximately 10-fold greater number of cells are processed than the expected library diversity. Performing a MACS selection enriches the library for clones that bind antigen and reduces library diversity to a level that can be processed via FACS.
Calculate the OD600 of the SDGCAA culture.
Transfer volume corresponding to 109 cells to a 50 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min at room temperature.
Discard the supernatant and wash the cells by resuspending in 25 mL PBSB.
Repeat Steps 9 and 10.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (room temperature) and discard the supernatant. Prepare 10% w/v milk solution in PBSB by dissolving 500 mg non-fat dry milk in 4.5 mL PBSB followed by end-over-end mixing at room temperature for 10–15 min.
Spin down milk solution at 2500×g for 5 min (room temperature). Move the supernatant to a new tube.
Note: Centrifuging the milk solution prior to use removes insoluble aggregates and produces more consistent results.
Resuspend the cells in a final volume of 5 mL with 1% milk (dilute 10% milk solution in PBSB from Step 12) and 300 nM of biotinylated monovalent antigen (e.g., SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain).
Incubate cells with antigen for 3 h with end-over-end mixing at room temperature.
Post antigen incubation, centrifuge the cells at 2500xg for 5 min and wash the cells once by resuspending in 25 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (room temperature).
Discard the supernatant.
Re-suspend the cells in 40 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Add 750 μL Miltenyi MACS Streptavidin MicroBeads to the resuspended cells.

Incubate the cells and beads with end-over-end mixing at 4°C for 30–45 min.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500xg for 5 min and wash the cells once by resuspending in 25 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (room temperature).
Discard the supernatant.
Pass the cells through a LS column under a magnetic field.
Note: LS columns are gravity columns. Before passing cells through them, they need to be placed on magnetic adapter (MidiMACS Separator and MACS MultiStand). Refer to manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0001298.PDF[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/upload/assets/IM0001298.PDF]) for more details.
Optional: Pass cells through a 70 μm filter immediately prior to running cells through the LS columns. Filtering cells removes aggregates and allows cells to pass through the column without clogging.
Wash the captured beads once by passing 5 mL ice-cold PBSB through the LS column under the magnetic field.
Remove the LS column from the magnet and elute beads by passing 5 mL SDCAA through the column.
Transfer eluted beads and cells to a 50 mL SDCAA media.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Plate dilutions (10–1000× from the 50 mL cultures) of the cell culture on yeast dropout plates to evaluate the numbers of cells retained during the selection.
Grow cells in SDCAA culture and on dropout plates at 30°C at 225 RPM for 2 d. The culture OD600 is typically >8–10 after 2 d of growth.
Pause point: Cells in SDCAA culture can be stored at 4°C for several weeks. After storing at 4°C, cells should be refreshed in fresh SDCAA for 18–24 h prior to induction in SDGCAA.
Fluorescence-activated cell sorting, FACS (sorts prior to CDR shuffling)
Timing: 5 h

FACS selections performed prior to CDR shuffling enrich the sorted library to obtain a population of yeast cells from which binding signal can be easily distinguished from the background. This stage of sorting maintains or sequentially decreases the antigen concentration in order to selection for a binding population that displays modest affinity for the target antigen.
Induce the yeast cells collected in sort 1 in SDGCAA media as described above in Steps 3–6. Culture volume at this stage may be decreased to 5–8 mL.
Calculate the OD600 of the SDGCAA culture.
Transfer volume corresponding to 107–108 yeast cells (adjusted to sample 10-fold greater number of cells compared to the isolated library diversity in the previous sort) to a sterile 1.5 mL tube. Typically, at least 107 cells are prepared to enable collection of at least 3,000–5,000 cells.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL of PBSB.
Repeat Steps 30 and 31.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Incubate the cells with antigen.
Resuspend ∼100–1000 nM antigen (see Note on determining concentrations below) and cell solution in a final volume of 200 μL in a sterile 1.5 mL tube along with a 1:1000 dilution of mouse anti-Myc tag antibody.
Incubate with antigen at room temperature for 3 h with end-over-end mixing.
A control sample containing the cells and all reagents except for the antigen should also be included.
Critical: It is recommended to sample at least 10-fold coverage of nanobody diversity in the early FACS selections (e.g., rounds 2–3) to sample full diversity obtained from the MACS selections (e.g., round 1).

Note: Reducing the antigen concentration in progressive rounds of sorting allows for the separation and selection of nanobodies with higher affinities.
Note: It is recommended to prepare samples at two different concentrations for sorting. In cases in which enrichment for clones that bind to the antigen is modest, it is recommended that the samples are prepared with the same antigen concentration and a three-fold dilution compared to the previous round. In cases in which enrichment for clones progresses rapidly between rounds, it recommended that the samples are prepared with three-fold and 10-fold reductions in antigen concentration compared to the previous round. Collection of cells from the lower of the two examined antigen concentrations that shows a distinct binding population typically allows for more efficient isolation of nanobodies with increased affinity.
Optional: Add milk to achieve a final concentration of 1% milk. The presence of milk may help in reducing the collection of nanobodies with poor specificity.
Post primary incubation, centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Wash the cells once by resuspending them in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in ice-cold secondary labeling reagents and incubate on ice for 4 min.
Prepare secondary labeling solution in ice-cold PBSB
Add a 1:200 dilution (final concentration of ∼10 μg/mL) of goat anti-mouse IgG AlexaFluor 488 for detection of nanobody expression on yeast surface.
For a bivalent antigen (antigen-Fc fusion protein), add a 1:300 dilution (final concentration of ∼5 μg/mL) of goat anti-human Fc IgG AlexaFluor 647 for detection of antigen binding.
For a monovalent biotinylated antigen, add a 1:1000 dilution (final concentration of ∼2 μg/mL) of streptavidin AlexaFluor 647 for detection of antigen binding.

Note: Nanobody expression and antigen binding can be detected using different fluorophores. For optimal sorting results, it is recommended to choose fluorophores with minimal overlap in their emission spectra.
Post-secondary incubation, centrifuge the cells at 16,000xg for 1 min (room temperature) and wash the cells once by resuspending them in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Place cells on ice.
Immediately before loading cells into a cell sorter, resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Critical: Cells should be resuspended immediately prior to sorting in order to prevent dissociation of nanobody-antigen binding. Keep cells and PBSB on ice for use in sorting.
Sort the cells on a cell sorter, such as a Beckman Coulter MoFlo Astrios, under sterile conditions.
Examine a plot of the forward scatter (FSC) and side scatter (SSC) of the yeast cells using the 488 nm laser.
Adjust the FSC and SSC voltages such that the population of cells spread out in a diagonal line (See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1369-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. FACS selections incorporating CDR-swapping mutagenesis enable rapid selection of high-affinity nanobodies

The nanobody library is sorted first using MACS (e.g., one MACS sort against monovalent SARS-CoV-2 receptor binding domain, RBD). Next, the enriched library is sorted by FACS against bivalent antigen (e.g., RBD-Fc) at relatively high antigen concentrations, and then it is further sorted by FACS against monovalent antigens (e.g., monovalent RBD) and/or at reduced antigen concentrations. A diagonal gate is drawn during FACS selections to collect yeast cells that bind antigen in a manner that is proportional to nanobody expression to enrich for high-affinity clones. The gates are drawn to minimize the percentage of cells appearing within the gates in the control sample to avoid enrichment of nanobodies that bind the secondary reagents. After several rounds of enriching the library via FACS, yeast plasmid DNA is isolated and CDR-swapping mutagenesis is performed. Finally, additional FACS sorts are performed following CDR-swapping mutagenesis to isolate high-affinity nanobodies.
Draw a gate surrounding the main population of cells in the plot of FSC versus SSC such that events in the bottom left-hand corner (dead cells and debris) are not included.
Filter the cells from within the gate on the FSC versus SSC plot into a subplot. This subplot should be used to examine the log area of signal from the fluorophore used to detect nanobody expression on the x-axis and the log area of the signal for the fluorophore used to detect antigen binding on the y-axis.
Analyze a control sample to assess nanobody expression and secondary reagent binding. This sample should be labeled with primary and secondary antibodies for detecting nanobody expression as well as secondary reagent for detecting antigen binding.
Adjust voltages for lasers exciting the fluorophores for detecting nanobody expression and antigen binding.

Adjust the voltage for the laser used for detecting nanobody expression such that two distinct cell populations are observed (See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
One population (left) is cells that do not express nanobodies on their surface.
The other population (right) is cells that express nanobodies.
Quadrants may be drawn to guide distinguishing the nanobody non-expressing and expressing cells.
Adjust the voltage for the laser used for detecting antigen binding such that signal from this laser is minimal in the control sample.
Voltage should be adjusted such that the signal is spaced away from the cytogram axis.
Voltage and quadrants should be adjusted such that minimal signal is seen in the upper two quadrants.
Analyze positive samples to assess both nanobody expression and antigen binding. Positive samples should include samples in which cells have been incubated with antigen at desired concentrations and labeled with the secondary reagent for detecting bound antigen. These samples should also be labeled with primary and secondary reagents for detecting antibody expression.
Draw a gate for cell collection in the upper right-hand quadrant of the cytogram.
Gate should be drawn sufficiently above the horizontal line dividing the quadrants such that a minimal number of cells fall within this gate in the control sample.
Gate should be drawn to have a diagonal slope on the right side.
Critical: Drawing a collection gate which minimizes the number of cells present in the control sample is critical to avoid enrichment of nanobodies that bind to secondary labeling reagents.
Sort cells and transfer into an 8 mL SDCAA culture.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Grow cells in SDCAA culture at 30°C at 225 RPM for 2 d.

Pause point: Cells in SDCAA culture can be stored at 4°C for several weeks. After storing at 4°C, cells should be refreshed in fresh SDCAA for 18–24 h prior to induction in SDGCAA.
Recovering nanobody library plasmids
Timing: 1.5 h
This step isolates the plasmid DNA from the enriched library that will be used as a template for CDR shuffling.
Obtain 1 mL of the 8 mL SDCAA culture collected in final FACS sort prior to CDR-swapping mutagenesis.
Note: Remaining cell culture can be stored at 4°C for several weeks. For long-term storage, cells can be frozen at −80°C in a solution of 30% glycerol and 0.67% yeast nitrogen base (without amino acids).
Recover nanobody library plasmids from 1 mL of sorted cells using a Zymo Yeast Miniprep Kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_D2004_Zymoprep_Yeast_Plasmid_Miniprep_II.pdf[href=https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_D2004_Zymoprep_Yeast_Plasmid_Miniprep_II.pdf]).
PCR amplification and shuffling of nanobody CDR genes
Timing: 2 days
DNA segments encoding individual CDRs and overlapping constant regions of the nanobodies are amplified. DNA-encoding nanobodies, which consist of combinations of the individual CDRs, are then reassembled via overlap PCR.
Amplify individual CDR genes (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]) by mixing DNA isolated in Step 54 with Q5 DNA polymerase and associated reagents (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_1369_12.csv
Amplify DNA segment including CDR1 (N-terminal homology-framework 1 to framework 2) using Forward primer #1 and Reverse primer #1.
Amplify DNA segment including CDR2 (framework 2 to framework 3) using Forward primer #2 and Reverse primer #2.
Amplify DNA segment including CDR3 (framework 3 to framework 4-C-terminal homology) using Forward primer #3 and Reverse primer #3.
Place PCR tubes in PCR block with a heated lid and run PCR at the following conditions.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1369_13.csv
Pause point: PCR products can be stored at 4°C overnight (∼12–24 h).

Purify the PCR product by separation using a 1% agarose gel followed by cutting the DNA bands at the expected size.
Cut band corresponding to ∼190–200 bp for PCR amplifying CDR1 for given primers.
Cut band corresponding to ∼160–170 bp for PCR amplifying CDR2 for given primers.
Cut band corresponding to ∼200–210 bp for PCR amplifying CDR3 for given primers.
Pause point: Agarose gel pieces containing amplified DNA can be stored at 4°C overnight (∼12–24 h).
Isolate DNA segments using a Qiagen Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706]).
Pause point: Isolated DNA can be stored at −20°C.
Mix amplified PCR products corresponding to each CDR gene in equal mass ratio along with terminal primers, Q5 polymerase, and reagents described below (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]) in a PCR tube to perform overlap PCR.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1369_14.csv
Place PCR tube in a PCR block with a heated lid and run PCR at the same conditions as Step 56.
Note: Sufficient replicates (16–32 of the above described 50 μL PCR reactions is usually sufficient) of this overlap PCR reaction should be performed in order to generate 12 μg of insert DNA.
Pause point: PCRs can be stored at 4°C overnight (∼12–24 h).
Purify the PCR product by separation using a 1% agarose gel followed by cutting the DNA band at the expected size (∼520 base pairs for the given primers).
Isolate insert DNA using a Qiagen Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706]).
Incubate vector with NheI-HF and XhoI restriction enzymes at 37°C overnight (∼12–18 h) according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/07/optimizing-restriction-endonuclease-reactions[href=https://www.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/07/optimizing-restriction-endonuclease-reactions]).
Note: Sufficient DNA should be digested in order to generate 4 μg of digested vector DNA (pCTCON2).
Add Quick CIP (calf intestinal alkaline phosphatase) to restriction digest reaction and incubate at 37°C for at least 15 min.

Purify the digested vector by separation using a 1% agarose.
Isolate digested vector DNA using a Qiagen Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706]).
Note: Digested vector DNA should be stored frozen at −20°C until use.
CDR-shuffled nanobody library generation
Timing: 5 days
Plasmid DNA encoding the CDR-shuffled nanobodies is transformed into yeast cells to generate a library for subsequent sorting.
Mix 12 μg of insert DNA (from Step 62) with 4 μg linearized plasmid (from Step 66).
Ethanol precipitate DNA with Pellet Paint NF Co-precipitant according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.emdmillipore.com/US/en/product/Pellet-Paint-NF-Co-Precipitant,EMD_BIO-70748#anchor_USP[href=https://www.emdmillipore.com/US/en/product/Pellet-Paint-NF-Co-Precipitant,EMD_BIO-70748#anchor_USP]).
Cover ethanol precipitated DNA with aluminum foil and allow to dry completely overnight in a vacuum or chemical fume hood at room temperature.
Transform ethanol precipitated DNA into EBY100 yeast cells.
Note: The protocol below is adapted from previously reported yeast library transformation protocols (Benatuil et al., 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Desai et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Julian et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Zupancic et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
Two days before transforming the library, start a 5 mL culture of EBY100 yeast cells and grow cells overnight (∼12–18 h) at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPM.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
One day before transforming the library, seed a 50 mL culture of EBY100 yeast cells from the 5 mL culture started the previous day and grow cells overnight (∼12–24 h) at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPM.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
The day that the library will be transformed, inoculate a culture of EBY100 yeast cells from the 50 mL culture started the previous day to achieve a final OD600 of 0.3.
Start 50 mL of culture per library to be transformed.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.

Grow cells at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPM.
Grow cells until the OD600 reaches a value of ∼1.6.
Note: The culture should reach the proper OD600 value in ∼5–6 h.
Transfer 50 mL of the EBY100 cells to a 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 25 mL sterile ice-cold DI water.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 25 mL sterile ice-cold electroporation buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 25 mL sterile ice-cold conditioning buffer.
Incubate the cells at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPMfor 15 min in a culture flask (baffled or non-baffled).
Transfer 25 mL of cells in conditioning buffer to 50 mL centrifuge tubes.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in 25 mL sterile ice-cold electroporation buffer.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in ice-cold electroporation buffer to a final volume of 400 μL.
Note: Approximately 100–200 μL of electroporation buffer should be added to achieve this final volume.
Resuspend the ethanol precipitated DNA in the prepared cells and electroporation buffer.
Transfer the cells to a 2 mm electroporation cuvette and place on ice for 5 min.
Electroporate cells using an appropriate electroporator, such as Bio-Rad Gene Pulser Xcell.
Set the voltage to 2500 V.
Set the resistance to 200 Ω.
Set the capacitance to 25 μF.
Immediately add 1 mL of a 1:1 mixture of YPD and 1 M sorbitol mixture to the cells.

Transfer the cells to a 14 mL culture tube and add 1:1 YPD:sorbitol to achieve a final volume of 8 mL.
Incubate the cells at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPMfor 1 h.
Centrifuge the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (room temperature) and discard the supernatant.
Transfer the cells to 200 mL of SDCAA.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Plate dilutions of the cell culture on yeast dropout plates to evaluate the number of transformants.
Grow the cells in SDCAA and dropout plates at 30°C with agitation at 225 RPMfor 2 days.
Pause point: A library in SDCAA culture can be stored at 4°C for several weeks. After storing at 4°C, the library should be refreshed in SDCAA for 18–24 h prior to induction in SDGCAA. For long-term storage, the library may be frozen at −80°C in solution of 30% glycerol and 0.67% yeast nitrogen base (without amino acids).
Fluorescence-activated cell sorting (sorting after CDR shuffling)
Timing: 5 h
FACS selections performed after CDR shuffling enrich the shuffled library to obtain nanobodies with high affinity. Sorts in this stage of the process may substantially decrease the antigen concentration in order to select for high-affinity nanobodies.
Induce the CDR-swapped library in 200 mL SDGCAA media.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Calculate the OD600 of the SDGCAA culture.
Transfer volume corresponding to 107 yeast cells to a sterile 1.5 mL tube.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL PBSB.
Repeat Steps 100 and 101.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.

Incubate the cells with the desired concentration of antigen (see note below).
Resuspend antigen and cell solution in a final volume of 200 μL in a sterile 1.5 mL tube with a 1:1000 dilution of mouse anti-Myc tag antibody.
Incubate with antigen at room temperature for 3 h with end-over-end mixing.
Antigen concentration should be maintained or reduced in progressive rounds of sorting.
Note: For the sort immediately following generation of the CDR-swapped library, antigen concentration should be maintained at the value used in the last selection before library generation.
Note: Subsequent rounds of sorting should further decrease the antigen concentration in order to select for high-affinity nanobodies. Preparation of samples with antigen at two distinct concentrations is recommended (as described above) because round-to-round enrichment is difficult to predict. Collection of cells from the lower of the two examined antigen concentrations typically allows for more efficient collection nanobodies with increased affinity.
Post primary incubation, centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min and discard supernatant.
Wash the cells once by resuspending them in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in ice-cold secondary labeling reagents and incubate on ice for 4 min.
Prepare secondary labeling solution in ice-cold PBSB
Add a 1:200 dilution (final concentration of ∼10 μg/mL) of goat anti-mouse IgG AlexaFluor 488 for detection of nanobody expression on yeast surface.
For a monovalent biotinylated antigen, add a 1:1000 dilution (final concentration of ∼2 μg/mL) of streptavidin AlexaFluor 647 for detection of antigen binding.
Post-secondary incubation, centrifuge the cells at 16,000xg for 1 min and wash the cells once by resuspending in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.

Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Place cells on ice.
Immediately before loading cells into a cell sorter, resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL ice-cold PBSB.
Sort the cells as described in Steps 43–52.
Recovering nanobody library plasmids
Timing: 1.5 h
Plasmids encoding nanobodies selected in the final round of sorting are isolated, and the sequences of selected nanobodies are determined.
Obtain 1 mL of the 8 mL SDCAA culture collected in the final FACS sort (after CDR shuffling).
Recover nanobody library plasmids from 1 mL of sorted cells using a Zymo Yeast Miniprep Kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_D2004_Zymoprep_Yeast_Plasmid_Miniprep_II.pdf[href=https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_D2004_Zymoprep_Yeast_Plasmid_Miniprep_II.pdf]).
Monovalent nanobody affinity analysis on yeast
Timing: 5 h
Monovalent nanobody affinities are determined for individual nanobodies displayed on the surface of yeast. Yeast cells displaying nanobodies selected from the final round of sorting are incubated with a range of antigen concentrations, and binding signals are measured using flow cytometry. Binding curves can then be fit to the data in order to calculate dissociation constants for monovalent nanobodies.
Start a 5 mL culture of EBY100 cells containing individual nanobody plasmids isolated from the terminal selection using CDR-swapping mutagenesis in SDCAA.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.
Incubate the culture at 30°C at 225 RPM for 18–24 h
Measure the OD600 of the SDCAA culture and calculate the volume of cells from the above culture required to seed a 5 mL SDGCAA culture at a final OD600 of 1.
Centrifuge the corresponding volume of cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in SDGCAA, and move the cells to a 5 mL SDGCAA culture.
Supplement culture with 100 μg/mL ampicillin, 100 μg/mL kanamycin, and 0.01× Pen-strep.

Incubate the culture at 20°C at 225 RPM for 36–48 h
Measure the OD600 of the SDCAA culture and calculate the volume of cells required to obtain 1 × 105 yeast cells per antigen concentration to be examined.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL PBSB.
Repeat Steps 121 and 122 once.
Centrifuge the cells in a tabletop centrifuge at 16,000×g for 1 min (room temperature) and discard supernatant.
Prepare antigen dilutions in PBSB with a final concentration of 1% milk in individual wells of a 96-well plate.
Add 1:1000 mouse anti-Myc antibody.
Add 1 × 105 cells to each well containing antigen and incubate at 350 RPM at room temperature for 3 h.
Centrifuge the plate containing the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Wash the cells once by resuspending them in 200 μL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the plate containing the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in ice-cold secondary labeling reagents and incubate on ice for 4 min.
Prepare secondary labeling solution in ice-cold PBSB
Add 1:200 dilution (final concentration of ∼10 μg/mL) of goat anti-mouse IgG AlexaFluor 488 for detection of nanobody expression on yeast surface.
For a monovalent biotinylated antigen, add 1:1000 dilution (final concentration of ∼2 μg/mL) of streptavidin AlexaFluor 647 for detection of antigen binding.
Centrifuge the plate containing the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Wash the cells once by resuspending them in 200 μL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the plate containing the cells at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the cells in ice-cold PBSB and immediately analyze by flow cytometry.

Analyze the antigen binding signal of yeast cells expressing nanobodies on the surface.
Cloning nanobodies as Fc-fusion proteins
Timing: 3 days
Plasmids are generated for expressing selected nanobodies in a bivalent Fc-fusion format.
Prepare nanobody Fc-fusion plasmids in pTT5 vector or other equivalent vectors (e.g., pBIOCAM5). Amplify nanobody gene by PCR using terminal primers that have NheI and HindIII restriction sites.
Purify the insert by running on a 1% agarose gel
Cut bands corresponding to nanobody coding sequences.
Purify DNA using a Qiagen Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706]).
Digest purified insert and pTT5 vector with NheI-HF and HindIII-HF according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/07/optimizing-restriction-endonuclease-reactions[href=https://www.neb.com/protocols/2012/12/07/optimizing-restriction-endonuclease-reactions]). For the vector, add Quick CIP calf alkaline phosphatase to the reaction according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.neb.com/protocols/2019/06/04/protocol-for-dephosphorylation-of-5-ends-of-dna-using-quick-cip-neb-m0525[href=https://www.neb.com/protocols/2019/06/04/protocol-for-dephosphorylation-of-5-ends-of-dna-using-quick-cip-neb-m0525]).
Purify the digested insert using a Qiagen PCR Purification kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-pcr-purification-kit/?catno=28104[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-pcr-purification-kit/?catno=28104]).
Purify the digested vector by running on a 1% agarose gel. Purify DNA using a Qiagen Gel Extraction kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/dna-clean-up/qiaquick-gel-extraction-kit/?catno=28706]).
Ligate digested insert and linearized backbone with T4 ligase according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.neb.com/protocols/0001/01/01/dna-ligation-with-t4-dna-ligase-m0202[href=https://www.neb.com/protocols/0001/01/01/dna-ligation-with-t4-dna-ligase-m0202]).
Transform the ligated plasmids into competent DH5α cells.
Plate transformed cells on LB ampicillin plates and grow cells at 37°C for 18–20 h.
Pick individual colonies and grow in LB media supplemented with 100 μg/mL ampicillin overnight (∼18–24 h) at 37°C.
Isolate the plasmids from DH5α using a Qiagen Miniprep kit according to the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/plasmid-dna/qiaprep-spin-miniprep-kit/?catno=27106[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/plasmid-dna/qiaprep-spin-miniprep-kit/?catno=27106]).
Confirm plasmid sequence via Sanger sequencing.
Nanobody-Fc fusion protein expression
Timing: 1 week
Nanobody-Fc fusion proteins are expressed via transient transfection in a mammalian cell line.
Grow HEK293-6E cells in supplemented F17 media at 37°C with 5% CO2 and mild agitation (L’Abbé et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). Maintain and passage at a density of ∼1.8–2 million cells/mL.

Note: It is recommended to passage cells no more than 40 times.
Transfect cells with 15 μg of sequence confirmed nanobody Fc-fusion
Mix 15 μg plasmid, 45 μg PEI, and 3 mL un-supplemented F17 media and incubate at room temperature for 15–20 min.
Add prepared plasmid mixture to cells at a density of ∼1.8–2 million cells/mL in culture tubes containing ∼25 mL cell culture.
Add 750 μL of 20% w/v yeastolate to culture 24–48 h post transfection.
Grow cells for another 3–5 d at 37°C with 5% CO2 and mild agitation.
Centrifuge the cell cultures at 3500×g for 40 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new tube and add ∼0.5 mL Protein A agarose beads.
Incubate the supernatant and beads at 4°C overnight (∼12–24 h) with mild agitation.
Capture beads in filter columns under vacuum and wash with ∼50 mL of PBS.
Incubate beads with 0.1 M glycine (pH 3.0) for 15 min to elute the protein solution and collect it by centrifugation.
Buffer exchange the proteins into 20 mM acetate (pH 5.0) using Zeba desalting columns as per manufacturer’s protocol (https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/MAN0015751_2162579_89877-8_89882-3_89889-94_89807-8_Zeba_Desalting_UG.pdf[href=https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/MAN0015751_2162579_89877-8_89882-3_89889-94_89807-8_Zeba_Desalting_UG.pdf]).
Filter nanobody Fc-fusions through a 0.22 μm filter, aliquot, and store at −80°C until use.
Determine the protein concentrations by measuring the absorbance at 280 nm using a Nanodrop spectrophotometer and the purity using SDS-PAGE.
Nanobody-Fc affinity analysis
Timing: 5 h
Apparent affinities of bivalent nanobodies are determined for individual nanobodies formatted as Fc-fusion proteins. A range of soluble nanobody-Fc fusions are incubated with antigen immobilized on the surface of magnetic beads, and binding signals are measured using flow cytometry. Binding curves can then be fit to the data.
Prepare 1 × 105 antigen coated beads per sample to be examined.
Transfer beads to a 1.5 mL tube and place tube on DynaMagTM-2 Magnet.

Discard the liquid.
Wash the beads by resuspending in 1 mL of PBSB.
Place tube containing beads on the magnet for 2–3 min and discard the liquid.
Repeat sub steps c and d.
Resuspend the beads in 1 mL of 10% milk and mix for 1 h with end-over-end mixing to block the beads.
Place tube containing beads on the magnet and discard the liquid.
Wash the beads by resuspending in 1 mL of PBSB.
Place tube containing beads on the magnet for 2–3 min and discard the liquid.
Resuspend beads in PBSB (typically 0.1–1 mL of PBSB).
Thaw an aliquot of nanobody-Fc fusion protein.
Centrifuge nanobody-Fc fusion in a tabletop centrifuge at max speed for 5 min. Transfer supernatant to a fresh tube.
Note: Centrifuging nanobody-Fc fusion proteins helps to remove any aggregates generated during each freeze/thaw cycle and produces more consistent results.
Measure the A280 signal for each nanobody using a Nanodrop to determine the protein concentration.
Prepare dilutions of nanobody-Fc fusion proteins in PBSB supplemented with 1% milk at concentrations (e.g., 0.1–1000 nM) desired for analysis.
Add 1 × 105 antigen-coated beads to antibody dilutions in each well of a 96-well plate.
Incubate soluble nanobody-Fc fusions and beads at 350 RPM and room temperature for 3 h in a final volume of 200 μL.
Centrifuge the plate containing the beads at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Wash the beads once by resuspending them in 200 μL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the plate containing the beads at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the beads in 200 μL ice-cold secondary labeling reagents and incubate on ice for 4 min.
Prepare secondary labeling solution in ice-cold PBSB

Add 1:300 dilution (final concentration of ∼5 μg/mL) of goat anti-human IgG AlexaFluor 647 for detection of antigen binding.
Centrifuge the plate containing the beads at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Wash the beads once by resuspending them in 200 μL ice-cold PBSB.
Centrifuge the plate containing the beads at 2500×g for 5 min (4°C) and discard supernatant.
Resuspend the beads in ice-cold PBSB and immediately analyze by flow cytometry.
Analyze the antigen-binding signal of the singlet population of beads.
